articles.headline: Consumers Are Dealt a New Hand in Credit Cards
articles.snippet: A primer on the new restrictions that credit card companies face, and some reassurances on those rewards programs.
articles.abstract: A primer on the new restrictions that credit card companies face, and some reassurances on those rewards programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: At first glance, the sweeping credit card legislation that passed the Senate on Tuesday looks like a huge victory for consumers. The bill, after all, contains relief from penalty fees and certain interest rate spikes.

articles.headline: 2 Firms Accused of Fraud in Debt Settlement
articles.snippet: The New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, sued two large debt settlement firms Tuesday, saying they engaged in fraudulent practices.
articles.abstract: The New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, sued two large debt settlement firms Tuesday, saying they engaged in fraudulent practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: The New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, sued two large debt settlement companies Tuesday, saying they had engaged in fraudulent and deceptive business practices and false advertising.

articles.headline: Vermont Acts to Make Drug Makers’ Gifts Public
articles.snippet: Soon citizens will be able to learn which doctors have been paid and how much by the makers of the brand name drugs for which they wrote prescriptions.
articles.abstract: Soon citizens will be able to learn which doctors have been paid and how much by the makers of the brand name drugs for which they wrote prescriptions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cracking down on medical industry payments to doctors, the Vermont legislature has passed a law requiring drug and device makers to publicly disclose all money given to physicians and other health care providers, naming names and listing dollar amounts.

articles.headline: Democrats in Senate Block Money to Close Guantánamo
articles.snippet: In an abrupt shift, Senate Democratic leaders said they would not provide the $80 million President Obama requested to close the detention center.
articles.abstract: In an abrupt shift, Senate Democratic leaders said they would not provide the $80 million President Obama requested to close the detention center.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In an abrupt shift, Senate Democratic leaders said they would not provide the $80 million that President Obama requested to close the detention center at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. The move escalates pressure on the president, who on Thursday is scheduled to outline his plans for the 240 terrorism suspects still held there.

articles.headline: Arms Sent by U.S. May Be Falling Into Taliban Hands
articles.snippet: Evidence suggests munitions procured by the Pentagon leak from Afghan forces for use against American troops.
articles.abstract: Evidence suggests munitions procured by the Pentagon leak from Afghan forces for use against American troops.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL  Insurgents in Afghanistan, fighting from some of the poorest and most remote regions on earth, have managed for years to maintain an intensive guerrilla war against materially superior American and Afghan forces.

articles.headline: In U.S., Steps Toward Industrial Policy in Autos
articles.snippet: Recent steps by the administration to address the problems in Detroit point to a policy approach used in Japan that had been shunned by the United States.
articles.abstract: Recent steps by the administration to address the problems in Detroit point to a policy approach used in Japan that had been shunned by the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama has cast himself as a reluctant interventionist in two of the nation’s major industries, Wall Street and Detroit. The federal aid, he says, is a financial bridge to a postcrisis future and the hand-holding will be temporary.

articles.headline: U.S. Weighs How to Let Banks Give Money Back
articles.snippet: Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley are among banks awaiting federal approval to pay back the funds and escape government controls.
articles.abstract: Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley are among banks awaiting federal approval to pay back the funds and escape government controls.
articles.lead_paragraph: It began on Oct. 13, in an atmosphere of panic, with an ultimatum from Washington. Now, the nation’s largest banks see a chance to bring an end to the bailout era.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Eric Dash

articles.headline: In Japan, Secure Jobs Have a Cost
articles.snippet: Some are questioning the system, bolstered by government subsidies, that keeps otherwise idle workers occupied.
articles.abstract: Some are questioning the system, bolstered by government subsidies, that keeps otherwise idle workers occupied.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSAKA, Japan  When the sheet metal orders coming into his small business, High Metal, fell by half last October, it never occurred to Masaaki Taruki to lay off his workers.

articles.headline: Sodas a Tempting Tax Target
articles.snippet: The possibility of a tax on sugary beverages is more plausible, now that an avid proponent has been appointed to a top public health position.
articles.abstract: The possibility of a tax on sugary beverages is more plausible, now that an avid proponent has been appointed to a top public health position.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Sugar, rum and tobacco are commodities which are nowhere necessaries of life, which are become objects of almost universal consumption, and which are therefore extremely proper subjects of taxation.”

articles.headline: Report Details Abuses in Irish Reformatories
articles.snippet: A nine-year investigation into Ireland’s Catholic-run institutions reported abuse from the 1930s to the 1990s.
articles.abstract: A nine-year investigation into Ireland’s Catholic-run institutions reported abuse from the 1930s to the 1990s.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  Tens of thousands of Irish children were sexually, physically and emotionally abused by nuns, priests and others over 60 years in a network of church-run residential schools meant to care for the poor, the vulnerable and the unwanted, according to a report released in Dublin on Wednesday.

articles.headline: U.S. Insurer of Pensions Sees Flood of Red Ink
articles.snippet: The increase in the last six months of $22.5 billion is largely a result of bankruptcies among companies whose pensions the agency must take over.
articles.abstract: The increase in the last six months of $22.5 billion is largely a result of bankruptcies among companies whose pensions the agency must take over.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The deficit at the federal agency that guarantees pensions for 44 million Americans tripled in the last six months to a record high, reaching $33.5 billion, largely as a result of surging bankruptcies among companies whose pensions it expects it will soon need to take over.
